Fluid Tools API 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT

Fluid Tools is a software composition framework.

See: Description

Packages 
Package Description
org.fluidity.composition
Dependency injection container interface and supporting artifacts.
org.fluidity.composition.container
Service provider interfaces to be used by the dependency injection container implementation.
org.fluidity.composition.container.spi
Service provider interfaces to be implemented by the dependency injection container implementation.
org.fluidity.composition.spi
Service provider interfaces to handle special cases of software composition in Fluid Tools.
org.fluidity.composition.web
Web application life-cycle to container life-cycle adapter.
org.fluidity.deployment.cli
Command line application support.
org.fluidity.deployment.launcher
Various application launchers that bootstrap the Fluid Tools dependency injection containers.
org.fluidity.deployment.osgi
Managed component model for OSGi services, and components depending thereon.
org.fluidity.deployment.plugin.spi
Service provider interfaces for the standalone JAR/WAR/OSGi application Maven plugins.
org.fluidity.features
Fluid Tools features that are independent of the main Fluid Tools functionality.
org.fluidity.foundation
Utilities to support basic tasks.
org.fluidity.foundation.jarjar
Stream protocol handler to work with resources inside JAR archives embedded in other JAR archives.
org.fluidity.foundation.security  
org.fluidity.foundation.spi
Service provider interfaces for foundation utilities.
org.fluidity.foundation.testing
Utilities to simplify unit testing Fluid Tools components.
org.fluidity.management
Managed components for JMX.
org.fluidity.testing
Utilities to simplify unit testing with EasyMock.

Fluid Tools is a software composition framework. As a framework, it provides a frame to your application and once you have that frame set up, it becomes virtually invisible, thus allowing you to focus on your code rather than its frame.

Fluid Tools also gives you basic and more advanced utilities that Fluid Tools itself makes extensive use of, internally.

Fluid Tools does not conform to JSR 330: Dependency Injection for Java and we don't consider that to be a deficiency in Fluid Tools.

To get started with Fluid Tools, see the Getting Started guide. For a complete documentation, see the User Guide.
